Rather to lose a soul, then lose a jest.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Ill terms my friend, this wit in any man,
(For that but seasoned with discretion)
Holds him in awe of all these blemishes,
Frees him of envy, doth philosophize
His spirit, that he makes no difference
Twixt man and man, twixt fortunes high and low,
But as the thicker they with virtues grow,
Freedom and bondage wit can make alone;
So 'twould by being left, and being loved,
If I had any of it tempered so:
But you have spoke all this condemning me,
For having wit to speak against myself,
But I'll be ruled by you in all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Then thus:
Tonight by promise, I do give a mask,
As to congratulate the bridal day,
In which the count, Pendant, and the wise knight,
Will be most worthy dancers, sir you shall,
Learn but my part, which I will teach you to,
As nimbly as the usher did teach me,
And follow my further directions,
Though I i'th morn were a prodigious wight,
I'll give thee Bellafront in thine arms tonight .

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: I am your property, my engineer
Prosper your purposes, shine thou eye of heaven,
And make thy lowering morn, a smiling even.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Cap. Powts with a letter, and Strange like a soldier.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: O, these are Lambeth fields.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Strange murdered on the wedding day by you,
At his own bride's appointment, for my sake?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: As dead as charity.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: This sounds not well.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Zounds, you may say as well I am the man,
As doubt he lives, a plague of your belief,
D'ye know this bloody ruff which she has sent,
Lest you should be incredulous, and this ring
Which you have seen her wear?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I know the ring,
And I have seen the ruff about his neck,
This comes of enforced marriages; where was't done?
And how escaped you?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Sir receive it briefly:
I am her kinsman, and being newly come
Over, and not intending to stay long,
Took this day to go see my cousin worldly,
(For so my name is) where I found all of them
So deeply drenched in the bridal cup,
That sleep had ta'en possession of their eyes;
Bacchus had given them such an overthrow,
Their bodies lay like slaughtered carcases;
One here, one there, making such antic faces,
As drunkenness had mocked at drunkenness,
Introth their postures and their sleep like death,
(For theirs, was liker death, then sober sleep)
Remembered me of body-scattered fields,
After the bloody battles I have seen,
'Twas such a season. To make short my tale,
As fate had said, now murders may be done
And never revealed, approaching further, I
Lighted upon a chamber, where your love
Sat by this merchant cast drunk on the bed,
She weeping and lamenting her mishap,
Assured both of my daring, and my trust,
Fell flat upon the ground, then raised herself,
Hung on my neck, then sunk down to my legs,
Told all things passed today, and never ceased
Till I had ta'en life from that half dead man
Before, whom straight I strangled with this rope.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You have showed some kindness to me, I must love you sir,
what did you with his body?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Having first
By her direction put on these his clothes,
That like the murdered man, the safelyer
I might pass with her, being her husband's shape,
If any of the servants had been waked,
She showed me to a necessary vault,
Within a closet in the chamber too,
And there I threw the body.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whence this blood?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That she herself first, let out of his veins,
Wherein she dipped the ruff about his neck:
And said, go bear this ensign of my love,
To assure him what I dared for his dear sake.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Where is the maid?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Captain a maid for you,
But well you know (I hope) she is no maid,
But maid or no maid, she is at my mothers,
Whence I will bring her whether you'll appoint
Tonight , and let this tide convey all hence,
For staying will be something perilous.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir, I will kill two men for you till then
I owe my life to you, and if ever racks,
Strappadoes, wheel, or any torturous engine,
Even from the Roman yoke, to the Scotch boot,
Force me discover you, or her, to law,
Pray God the merchant may respire again,
But what a villain have I been to wrong her?
Did she not tell you how I injured her?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: She said you challenged her, and publicly
Told you had lain with her, but truths no wrong.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Truth, was more false than hell, and you shall see me,
(As well, as I can repent of any sin)
Ask her forgiveness for wounding of her name,
And 'gainst the world recover her lost fame.
Kind soul, would I could weep, to make amends
Why I did slander her at the church door.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: The more base villain thou. Strike him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Thou unspeakable rascal, thou a soldier,
A captain of the suburbs, a poor forced,
That with thy slops, and cat a mountain's face,
Thy blather chops, and thy robustious words,
Frightest the poor whore, and terribly dost exact,
A weekly subsidy, twelve pence a piece,
Whereon thou liv'st, and on my conscience
Thou snap'st besides, with cheats and cutpurses.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Heart, this is some railing poet, why you rogue?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Thou rogue, far worse than rogues, thou slanderer

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Thou worse than slanderous rogues, thou murderer

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembered, I will cut thy throat,
To appease that merchant's soul, which never will rest,
Till some revenge be taken on thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I'll kill the first, and in thy vital flood,Fight.
Wash my hands clean of that young merchant's blood.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You fight as if you had fought afore,
I can still hold my sword, come on sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Zounds can you ward so well, I think you are one of the noble science of defence.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: True, a'th science of noble defence I am,
That fight in safeguard of a virtuous name. Cadit cap:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O, now I understand you, and you stand over me, my hurts are not mortal, but you have the better, if your name be worldly, be thankefull for your fortune.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Give me thy sword, or I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Some wiser than some, I love my reputation well, yet I am not so valiant an ass, but I love my life better, there's my

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Then get upon my back, come all shall be well.
I'll carry thee unto a surgeon first, and then unto thy wench, sword
Come we are friends.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Godamercy, zounds methinks I see myself in
Moorfields, upon a wooden leg, begging three pence.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I thank thee heaven for my success in this,
To what perfection is my business grown. Exit with Cap. on his back.
Seldom or never is right overthrown.

div.stage: Enter pendant, and mistress Wagtaile, with work sowing a purse.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: They say every woman has a springe to catch a woodcock, remember my instructions, and let me see what a paradise thou canst bring this fool into. 15. hundered a year wench, will make us all merry, but a fool to boot; why we shall throw the house out at window; let me see, there are two things in this foolish transitory world, which should be altogether regarded, profit and pleasure, or pleasure and profit, I know not which to place first, for indeed, they are twins, and were born together; for profit, this marriage (God speed it) marries you to it, and for pleasure, if I help you not to that as cheap as any man in England, call me cut, and so remember my instructions, for I'll go fetch sir Abraham. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Your instructions; nay faith, you shall see I have as fruitful a brain as a belly, you shall hear some additions of my own, my fantasy even kicks like my bastard: well boy, for I know thou art masculine, neither thy father nor thy mother had any feminine quality, but one, and that was to take a good thing when it was proffered; when thou inheritest land, strange both to thy father and grandfather, and ridest in a caroche, it may be thy father an old footman, will be running by thy side, but yonder comes the gentle knight, and my squire.

div.stage: Enter sir Abraham and pendant stealing.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Unfortunate damsel, why dost thou love
Where thou hast sworn it never to reveal?
May be he would vouchsafe to look on thee
Because he is a knight, is it thy terror,
Why peradventure he is knighthood's mirror.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: D'ye hear sir Abraham?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yes, with standing tears.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Beavis on Arundel with morglay in hand,
Near to my knight in prowess doth not stand;
They say sir Beavis flew both boar and dragon,
My knight for that can drink up a whole flagon,
a thing as famous now amongst our men,
As killing monsters were accounted then,
'Tis not thy leg, no, were it twice as good,
Throws me into this melancholy mood,
Yet let me say and swear, in a cross garter,
Poles never showed to eyes a lovelier quarter.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Ay, but all this while she does not name me, she may mean somebody else.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Mean somebody else, you shall hear her name you by and by.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Courteous sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: La ye there.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: O, thy very name,
Like to a hatchet cleaves my heart in twain,
When first I saw thee in those little breeches,
I laughed for joy, but when I heard thy speeches
I smiled down right, for I was almost frantic,
A modern knight should be so like an antic,
In words and deeds, those pinkanies of thine,
For I shall never be blessed to call them mine.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Say not so, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: How they did run not rheumatickly run,
But round about the room, one over one,
That wide mouth no, small, no, but middle-size,
That nose dominical, that head, like — wise.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Very good, d'ye mark that head like wise?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: She has an excellent wit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I'll now into her, sir observe what follows, now turtle mourning still for the party, for whom are you working that purse?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: For me I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What news good cousin, I hope you have not revealed my love.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Yes faith, I have acquainted the knight withal, and thou mayst be ashamed to abuse a gentleman to slanderously, he swears he never lay with you.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Lay with me, alas no, I say not so, nor no man living;
but there was one night above the rest, that I dreamt he lay with me, and did you never hear of a child begotten in a dream.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: By this light, that very night I dreamt she lay with me.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: I but sir Abra: is no dreaming knight: in short, he contemns you, he scorns you at his heels.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: By God so he lies, I have the most ado to forbear, but that I would hear a little more.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: And has sent this halter, you may hang yourself, or you may cut your throat, here's a knife too.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Well, I will love him in despite of all,
Howe'er he uses me, 'tis not the shame
Of being examined, or the fear of whipping.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Make as if thou wouldst kill thyself.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Should move me, would but he vouchsafe his love,
Bear him this purse filled with my latest breath. Blows in it
I loved thee Abraham Ninny, even in death. Offers to stab

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Hold, hold, thy knight commands thee for to hold,
I sent no halter, poor soul how it pants,
Take courage, look up.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Look, sir Abra: in person comes to see you.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O, let me die then in his worship's arms.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Live long and happy to produce thy baby,
I am thy knight, and thou shalt be my lady:
Frown dad, fret mother, so my love look cheerly,
Thou hast my heart, and thou hast bought it dear,
And for your pains, if Abraham live to inherit,
He will not be unmindful of your merit;
Wear thou this ring, whilst I thy labours task,
This purse wear in my cap, anon i'th mask.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O happy woman.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: To supper let's, and merry be as may be.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Now God send every wise knight such a lady.Exeunt

div.head: Scen. prima.
div.stage: Enter Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Titles and state d'ye call it: o content!
Thou art both beauty, means, and all in marriage:
Joy dwells not in the prince's palaces,
They that envy 'em do not know their cares,
Were I the Queen of gold, it could not buy
An hour's ease, for my oppressed heart.
O, were this wedlock knot to tie again,
Not all the state and glory it contains,
Joined with my father's fury, should enforce
My rash consent; but Scudmore thou shalt see,
This false heart (In my death) most true to thee.
sp.stage: Shows a knife hanging by her side.
sp.l: My lord, my father, all the company
Did note my sudden sadness now at supper,
Yet came I out, and put on feigned mirth,
And mean to sit out this nights revels too,
To avoid all suspect may grow in 'em,
Lest my behaviour should my intent reveal:
Our griefs (Like love) we hardly can conceal,
Yond comes my sisters: are the maskers ready?

div.stage: Enter Lucida with her willow garland on, and Katherine.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: They are gone to dress themselves, m. nevil's come
I would I had not vowed to live a maid,
I am a little taken with that gentleman,
And yet if marriage be so full of ill,
Let me be married to my garland still.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Introth thy state is happier much than ours,
Were never two (Like us) unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Thy case indeed, I needs must pity much,
Because I think thy virtue slandered,
But for my lady sister, if she reap
Sad discontent, 'tis nonce but her own fault,
I knew the passages twixt her and Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Sister, I wonder you will name a man,
I think not on, he was no match for me,
why d'ye blame me, that should rather blame
Your wandering eye, to love a man loved me,

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Well 'tis too late now to expostulate.
But my poor little Kate, where is thy man?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Lost, lost introth, tomorrow I shall hear,
I make account he's gone some five years voyage,
Till this disgrace of ours be overblown,
And for my captain Powts, by this time he
Is ten mile on the river towards graves's end.

div.stage: Enter sir John Wordly, with two with torches and cudgels.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Stand you two there, sirrah go you with me.
Why how now girls here still, what and your ladyship?
Away, away, I say, go take your places.
Some torches for my lady.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: You sirrah,Exeunt bell. Lucida, Kate.
Is my lady Ninny awake yet?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir, she is awake, but she is scant sober, the first thing she called for, was her aqua vitae bottle.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Who is with her?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The good sir innocent, and her gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Go tell 'em I desire their company,
The mask stays on 'em say, and d'ye hear,
The sides of one a'th chairs must be let out,
For her great ladyship.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Marry shall it sir. Exit servant.

div.stage: Enter Nevill, count, pendant, and sir Abraham in their masking robes, sir Abra: knawing on a capon's leg.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Soul man, leave eating now, look, look, you have all dropped a your suit.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: O sir, I was in love today, and could not eat, but here's one knows the case is altered, lend me but a handkerchief to wipe my mouth, and I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Soul, how this rascal stays with the rest of our things.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: How now son count, what ready m. Nevill.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: All ready, ready, only we tarry for our vizards and our caps, I put 'em to a knave to doing, because I would have 'em the better done.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: If you put 'em to a knave, you are like to have 'em the worse done.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Your wit is most active, I called him knave in regard of his long stay sir, not his work.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: But d'ye hear mayst Nevill, did you bespeak a vizard with a most terrible countenance for me.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: A very devil's face, I fear nothing but that it will fright the women.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I would it would, and a huge mustachioes?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: A very Turks.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But do you think he will come at all?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O, there he is. Speaks within,

div.stage: By your leave, stand back, by your leave. Enter Scudmore like a vizard-maker.
div.p: Nothing can be done tonight , if I enter not.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: Stand back there, or I'll burn you.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: 'Twere but a whorish trick sir.

sp.speaker: 3 servant
sp.p: O sir is't you, heart you'll be killed.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Marry God forbid sir.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Pray forbear, let me speak to him, o you use us very well.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: In good faith, I have been so troubled about this gentleman's scurvy face (I take it) 'tis wonderful.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Well, are you fitted now.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Fitted at all points.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Where are the caps.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Let me see mine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come help me on with mine.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: This a rare face to fright the maids i'th country, here now I'll pin my purse, come help me on.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: So, so, away, mine being on I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Pray make haste. Exeunt s. John, count, Pen.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: So that doors fast, and they are busied. S. Abra.
About their charge: on with this robe of mine,
This vizard and this cap; help me a little. Change habit.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: At first change I must tell her who I am?

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Right, 'tis agreed, I (Leading of the mask,)
Should dance with Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: And at the second, I come away with her, and leave them dancing, and shall find you at the back door.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: The rest
That follows, is digested in my breast.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What would you do? Stand back,
Unless you can eat torches.

div.stage: Enter count, Pend: sir Abrahm in their masking robes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come, come, away for shame.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: 'Tis such a tedious rascal. So ha w'ye.

div.stage: Exeunt maskers.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Thou hast well fitted 'em, though thou madest 'em stay.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: I forbid any man to mend 'em sir, good night unto your worship.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Alas sir, I have another to set forth
This very night: by your leave my masters.

div.stage: Exit Nevill through them.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: By your leave, by your leave, you'll let a man go out?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Now go with me, and let all in that will.

div.stage: Exit sir John with them, and ran in three or four.
Enter 2. or 3. setting 3. or 4. Chairs, and 4 or 5. stools.

Loud music, in which time, enter sir John worldly, sir Innocent, Bellafront, Lucida, Kate, my lady Ninny, Mrs. Wagtaile, they seat themselves, lady Ninny offers at two or three chairs; at last finds the great one: they point at her and laugh. As soon, as she is set, she drinks of her bowl, the music plays, and they enter.

After one strain of the music, Scudmore takes Bellafront, who seems unwilling to dance, count takes Lucida, pendant Kate, sir Abraham. Mistress Wagtaile, Scudmore as they stand, the other courting too, whispers as follows.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I am your Scudmore. Soft music.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: By heaven I am,
Be ruled by me in all things.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Even to death.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: 'Sfoot did you not know me by my purse?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I should never have known you by that, for you wear it on your head, and other folks in their pockets.

sp.speaker: La: Nin.
sp.p: Which is my lord I pray?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: The second man
Young Nevill leads.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: And where's sir. Abraham?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: He with the terrible visage.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.l: Now out upon him to disfigure himself so,
And 'twere not for my bottle, I should swoon.

div.stage: Music, and they dance, the second strain, in which scudm: goes away with her.

sp.speaker: Om. Spect.
sp.p: Good very good.

div.stage: The other four dance, another strain, honour and end.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But where's the bride and Nevill?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Beware tricks.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: O, there they come, it was their parts to do so

div.stage: Enter Scudmore unvizarded, Bellafront with pistols, and the right parson.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This Nevill, this is Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But here's my lady,

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: No my gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Zounds treason, I smell powder.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: In short know, that I am married to this gent.
To whom I was contracted long ago:
this priest the inviolable knot hath tied,
What ease I find being un-ladified.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What riddle's this?

sp.speaker: S. Inno.
sp.p: Ware the last statute of two husbands.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Bellafront, pish.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This is the very priest that married me,
Is it not sister?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: No.

div.stage: Enter Nevill like the parson too.

sp.speaker: Abra
sp.l: Lord bless us here is conjuring,
Lend me your aquavitae bottle good mother.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Heyday, the world's turned up side down, I have heard and seen two or three benefices to one priest, or more, but two priests to one benefice, never before.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Married not you the Earl?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Bonafide, no.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: You did then?

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have the privilege then.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Right, you were married first.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Sir John you dote,
This is a devil in a parson's coat.

div.stage: Nevil puts off the priest's weeds, and has a devil's robe under.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: A pretty emblem.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Who married her, or would have caused her marry
To any man but this, no better was,
Let circumstances be examined,
Yet here's one more, and now I hope you all,
Perceive my marrying not cannon call.

div.stage: Slips off his devil's weeds.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Nevill, whoop.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Heart, what a deal a knavery a priest's cloak can hide, if it be not one of the honestest friendliest cozenages that ere I saw, I am no lord.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Life, I am not married then in earnest.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: So mistress Kate, I kept you for myself.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: It boots not to be angry.

sp.speaker: S. In. la.
sp.p: No faith sir John.

div.stage: Enter Strange with Powts on his back.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: Whether will you go with your calf on your back sir.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Now more knavery yet.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Prithee forbear, or I shall do thee mischief: by your leave, here's some sad to your merriment: know you this captain?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Yes very well.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: O sister, here's the villain slandered me.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: You see he cannot stand to't.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Is he hurt in the arm too?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Why then by gods-lid thou art a base rogue, I knew I should live to tell thee so.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: Sir Abraham I say.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Heaven is just.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What a rogue are you, is this the surgeon you would carry me to?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Confess your slander, and I will I swear.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Nay 'tis no matter, I'll cry quittance with you,
Forgive me Mrs. Kate, and know all people
I lied not with her, but belied her once,
And to my recantation, that same soldier
Enforced my hand. They all look on the paper.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Yes, here 'tis mistress Kate.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I see now how I am cheated, love him well,
He has redeemed your honour with his sword.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: But where is strange my son, o were he here he should be married new to make all sure.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O my divining spirit, he's gone to sea.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This cunning in her is exceeding good,
Your son, your husband, strange is murdered.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Peace, peace, for heaven's sake peace,
Come sir, I'll carry you to a surgeon,
Here's gold to stop thy throat, for godsake peace.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sirrah, you have brought me to a surgeon already, I'll be even with you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Of all men living I could marry thee,
Were not my heart given to another man,
Sir you did speak of strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: These women are as crafty as the devil,
Yes, I did speak of him, sir John, my lord,
Know strange is murdered by that villain's hand,
And by his wife's consent.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: God forbid.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Search presently the closet and the vault,
There you shall find his body, 'tis too true,
The reason all may guess, her husband wanting
Spirit to do on me what he hath done,
In hope to marry her, he hath murdered him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: To marry me, no villain I do hate him
On this report, worse than I do thyself,
And may the plagues and tortures of a land
Seize me, if this be not an innocent hand.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Fore-god 'tis most like truth, son Scudmore pray
Look to this fellow, gentlemen assist,
Torches, some torches, I'll go search myself,

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: I will assist you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But I pray sir how came you unto this knowledge

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: From his mouth.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: I'll save your labour, and discover all:
Thou perjured villain, didst not swear thou wouldst not discover me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I but swore in jest.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Nay but remember thou didst wish strange living
If ever thou didst tell, sir all is true,
And would my punishment would ease my conscience.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: To Newgate with him hence, take her along,
Out murderers, whore thou art no child of mine,
Fetch constable and officers, away.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Sir do but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Fetch officers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Go fetch a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Stra,
sp.p: Sir, you are then too violent, I will bail her.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O my dear strange. Discovers himself.

sp.speaker: World,
sp.p: My son.

sp.speaker: Scud. Luci. Bell.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Young strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Heart, I was never sick before, help me now to a
Surgeon, or I shall swoon instantly. As 2 leads him he speaks
Thou were't born a roman-citizen, fare thee well,
And farewell love, and women, ye diseases,
My horse and sword shall be my mistresses,
My horse I'll court, my sword shall lie with me.Exit

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: The way to cure lust, is to bleed I see.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tell him all Scudmore, whilst I go a-wooing again, sir John will you go along, and my two worshipful elders, I pray be you witnesses, priest goNeu. Scud. bell. Stra. Kate. Whispers in one part. Pend. Sir Abra. and wag. in another.not you away, heart I have so ruminated on a wife, that I must have one this night, or I shall run proud. Mistress Lucida, you did once love me, if you do still, no more words, but give me your hand, why are ye doubtful?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Ne'er look upon me m. Lucida, time was, time is, and times past, I'll none of you now, I am otherwise provided.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Well spoken brazen head, now or never sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Then first as duty binds, I crave consent
Of my two parents dear: if I, say so;
If not, I'll ha' her, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: How. how.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: I hope you will not

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Mam, I am resolved, you have a humour of your aquavitae bottle, why should not I have a humour in a wife?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: An old man were a fitter match for her,
He would make much of her.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Much on her, I know not what ye call much making on her, I am sure I have made two on her.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: And that an old man cannot do I hope.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: O thou beyond Lawrence of Lancashire.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Speak not in vain, I am too sure to change,
For hand and heart are sure,
Ecce signum, and this have I done, and never lay with her

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Nay, then 'tis too late,
'Tis sure, 'tis vane to cross the will of fate.

sp.speaker: Sir In. la.
sp.p: Well, well, God bless you. Ab and wag kneel

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Thanks reverend couple, and God bless withal
The little ninny that herein doth sprawl,
Parson you shall dispatch us presently:
Lord how soberly you stand.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Now truly I could ne'er stand drunk in my life.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Strange and most fortunate, we must have a new tuck then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is it a match?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then Bacchus squeeze grapes with a plenteous hand.
Parson you'll take some pains with us tonight ;
Come brothers come, fly willow to the woods,
And like the sea, for healths let's drink whole floods.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I consecrate my deed unto this city,
And hope to live myself, to see the day,
It shall be shown to people in a play.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: And may all true love have like happy end,
Women forgive me; men, admire my friend.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: On parson on, and boy outvoice the music,
Never was so much (What cannot heavenly powers,)
Done and undone, and done in twelve short hours.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
